newsitem.title: GERMANY: Germany's Waigel mulls cut in EU contributions.
newsitem.headline: Germany's Waigel mulls cut in EU contributions.

text.p: German Finance Minister Theo Waigel is considering a plan under which Germany's payments to the European Union could be capped well below current levels, a finance ministry spokeswoman said on Wednesday.
The spokeswoman said the plan was one of a number of proposals for a fairer method of financing the EU being developed by the ministry.

The Die Zeit newspaper said Waigel planned to present the plan to the EU this autumn. It would cut nearly a third off Germany's current 22 billion mark annual contribution from the year 2000, the weekly paper said.
Under the plan, a country would get back two-thirds of all contributions it made that exceeded 0.3 percent of its gross national product.
With Germany's payments at around 0.6 percent of its GNP, this would mean a repayment of seven billion marks, Die Zeit said in a summary of an article to be published on Thursday.
The finance ministry spokeswoman said the details contained in the article summary were accurate but that concrete figures had not been settled in the proposal.

Both government and opposition politicians have complained recently that Germany's payments to the EU represent well over half all net contributions to the 15-nation bloc and are out of proportion with the size of its economy.
The German economy represents about a quarter of the EU's total gross domestic product.
German Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel called at the weekend for a change the way member states' EU payments were calculated.
But Kinkel said Germany would always pay more than other members as it was the main beneficiary of the EU's single market -- the destination for 75 percent of German exports.
